elements.content: This study evaluates the supramolecular reactivity of the 5-(4′-pyridyl)-10,15,20-tris(4′-iodophenyl)porphyrin (PyTIPP) and 5,15-bis(4′-pyridyl)-10,20-bis(4′-iodophenyl)porphyrin (PyDIPP) platforms in their free base and metalated forms, utilizing metal–ligand coordination and halogen bond synthons in the construction of polymeric as well as oligomeric assemblies. Free base PyTIPP and PyDIPP moieties form extended supramolecular layers held together by intermolecular N···I and I···π interactions, which π···π stack in an offset manner to yield layered crystals. The metalated monopyridyl derivative Co-PyTIPP (as well as its Zn-PyTIPP analogue) assembles into cyclic tetrameric supermolecule via coordination of the pyridyl function of one species to the core metal ion of an adjacent unit. On the other hand, the bis-pyridyl Zn-PyDIPP scaffold constructs a robust framework solid of extended honeycomb architecture by polymeric self-coordination. These findings provide useful protocols for rational design of the different modes of supramolecular porphyrin ensembles, which are valid in reaction media lacking polar reagents with competing affinity for the functional groups of the porphyrin units. In the latter context, PyDIPP in the presence of benzoic acid forms discrete solvated entities, where the pyridyl N-sites engage in hydrogen bonds to the carboxylic acids, preventing direct inter-porphyrin association.

Free base PyTIPP and PyDIPP moieties form extended supramolecular layers held together by intermolecular N⋅⋅⋅I and I⋅⋅⋅π interactions, which π⋅⋅⋅π stack in an offset manner to yield layered crystals. The metalated monopyridyl derivative Co-PyTIPP (as well as its Zn-PyTIPP analogue) assembles into cyclic tetrameric supermolecule via coordination of the pyridyl function of one species to the core metal ion of an adjacent unit. On the other hand, the bis-pyridyl Zn-PyDIPP scaffold constructs a robust framework solid of extended honeycomb architecture by polymeric self-coordination. These findings provide useful protocols for rational design of the different modes of supramolecular porphyrin ensembles, which are valid in reaction media lacking polar reagents with competing affinity for the functional groups of the porphyrin units. In the latter context, PyDIPP in the presence of benzoic acid forms discrete solvated entities, where the pyridyl N-sites engage in hydrogen bonds to the carboxylic acids, preventing direct inter-porphyrin association.

elements.content: Porphyrin derivatives containing mixed 4-pyridyl and 4-iodophenyl meso-substituents are excellent building blocks for demonstrating how to control the nature of their supramolecular self-assembly in crystals. The free-base scaffolds form flat extended layers held mainly by N···I and I···π halogen bonds. Monopyridyl core-metallated porphyrin yields discrete cyclic cage-type tetra-porphyrin oligomers, while trans-dipyridyl zinc-porphyrin assembles as a single-framework three-dimensional coordination polymer.
elements.clean_text: Porphyrin derivatives containing mixed 4-pyridyl and 4-iodophenyl meso-substituents are excellent building blocks for demonstrating how to control the nature of their supramolecular self-assembly in crystals. The free-base scaffolds form flat extended layers held mainly by N⋅⋅⋅I and I⋅⋅⋅π halogen bonds. Monopyridyl core-metallated porphyrin yields discrete cyclic cage-type tetra-porphyrin oligomers, while trans-dipyridyl zinc-porphyrin assembles as a single-framework three-dimensional coordination polymer.

elements.content: Design of attractive supramolecular architectures in the solid as well as in solution draws from a plethora of the available molecular recognition synthons and cooperativity of the intermolecular interactions. The porphyrins represent ideal building blocks for the formulation of supramolecular materials. They have topological diversity, minimal conformational flexibility, and can be readily functionalized at several different sites, and thus fine-tuned to self-assemble and self-organize in predefined architectures. Moreover, the potentially multidentate porphyrin platform is characterized by features of preorganization and potential for cooperative binding, which are essential for adequate enthalpic stabilization of the desired products. Others and we have surveyed some useful guidelines for patterning multi-porphyrin arrays in a series of earlier publications. In this context we continue to evaluate additional scaffolds with diverse (symmetric as well asymmetric) disposition of the topological binding sites, in order to test their effectiveness in noncovalent synthesis of new materials. The general goal is to define the principles and conditions that may lead to the construction of supramolecular bulk as well as nanostructures of high structural integrity, and provide effective algorithms for the rational design of self-organized porphyrin arrays. The present work focuses on porphyrins bearing mixed and complementary pyridyl and iodophenyl molecular recognition functions: 5-(4′-pyridyl)-10,15,20-tris(4′-iodophenyl)porphyrin (PyTIPP) and 5,15-bis(4′-pyridyl)-10,20-bis(4′-iodophenyl)-porphyrin (PyDIPP), along with their core-metalated derivatives (Scheme ). The free base moieties can self-assemble through N···I and I···I halogen bonds as well as I···π interactions, and their metal complexes also via metal···pyridyl coordination, all types representing reliable synthons in the supramolecular self-assembly of organic moieties. Here we demonstrate the self-assembly of the free-base PyTIPP scaffold into chiral layered assemblies directed by halogen bonds (compound 1). On the other hand, its metalated derivatives, Co and Zn-PyTIPP’s, form discrete cyclic tetramers (compounds 2 and 2a), which is in agreement with earlier observations that metalloporphyrins with axial coordination capacity and a single pyridyl substituent tend to self-organize into oligomeric capsules. Then again, the free-base PyDIPP aggregates in crystals in the form of extended layers via I···π contacts and π···π stacking of these layers (3). Finally, Zn-PyDIPP constructs robust zeolite-type honeycomb architecture via self-coordination (4), consistent with our discovery (subsequently confirmed by others) on the single-framework self-assembly mode of trans-dipyridyl derivatives of zinc-porphyrins. An example of competing solvation that interferes with direct supramolecular porphyrin assembly is represented by structure 5 of the 1:2 PyDIPP/benzoic acid solvate.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Design of attractive supramolecular architectures in the solid as well as in solution draws from a plethora of the available molecular recognition synthons and cooperativity of the intermolecular interactions. The porphyrins represent ideal building blocks for the formulation of supramolecular materials. They have topological diversity, minimal conformational flexibility, and can be readily functionalized at several different sites, and thus fine-tuned to self-assemble and self-organize in predefined architectures. Moreover, the potentially multidentate porphyrin platform is characterized by features of preorganization and potential for cooperative binding, which are essential for adequate enthalpic stabilization of the desired products. Others and we have surveyed some useful guidelines for patterning multi-porphyrin arrays in a series of earlier publications. In this context we continue to evaluate additional scaffolds with diverse (symmetric as well asymmetric) disposition of the topological binding sites, in order to test their effectiveness in noncovalent synthesis of new materials. The general goal is to define the principles and conditions that may lead to the construction of supramolecular bulk as well as nanostructures of high structural integrity, and provide effective algorithms for the rational design of self-organized porphyrin arrays. The present work focuses on porphyrins bearing mixed and complementary pyridyl and iodophenyl molecular recognition functions: 5-(4'-pyridyl)-10,15,20-tris(4'-iodophenyl)porphyrin (PyTIPP) and 5,15-bis(4'-pyridyl)-10,20-bis(4'-iodophenyl)-porphyrin (PyDIPP), along with their core-metalated derivatives (Scheme ). The free base moieties can self-assemble through N⋅⋅⋅I and I⋅⋅⋅I halogen bonds as well as I⋅⋅⋅π interactions, and their metal complexes also via metal⋅⋅⋅pyridyl coordination, all types representing reliable synthons in the supramolecular self-assembly of organic moieties. Here we demonstrate the self-assembly of the free-base PyTIPP scaffold into chiral layered assemblies directed by halogen bonds (compound 1). On the other hand, its metalated derivatives, Co and Zn-PyTIPP's, form discrete cyclic tetramers (compounds 2 and 2a), which is in agreement with earlier observations that metalloporphyrins with axial coordination capacity and a single pyridyl substituent tend to self-organize into oligomeric capsules. Then again, the free-base PyDIPP aggregates in crystals in the form of extended layers via I⋅⋅⋅π contacts and π⋅⋅⋅π stacking of these layers (3). Finally, Zn-PyDIPP constructs robust zeolite-type honeycomb architecture via self-coordination (4), consistent with our discovery (subsequently confirmed by others) on the single-framework self-assembly mode of trans-dipyridyl derivatives of zinc-porphyrins. An example of competing solvation that interferes with direct supramolecular porphyrin assembly is represented by structure 5 of the 1:2 PyDIPP/benzoic acid solvate.

All starting materials, reagents, and solvents were obtained commercially (Aldrich and Merck) and used without further purification.

Synthesis of Porphyrin Compounds

A total of 1.25 g (5.4 mmol) of 4-iodobenzaldehyde, 0.34 mL (3.6 mmol) of 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde were added to 35 mL of hot propionic acid at 120 °C. Then 0.5 mL of distilled pyrrole (7.21 mmol) was added, and the resulting solution was heated to refluxing for 90 min. The solvent was then removed by vacuum distillation, and the crude product was digested with hot water to remove traces of propionic acid, filtered, washed with water, and dried. The crude porphyrin mixture was dissolved in chloroform and loaded on a silica gel 60 (Merck) column using chloroform.

elements.content: The free-base porphyrins PyTIPP or PyDIPP (∼0.05 g) were dissolved in 25 mL of CHCl3. To each of these samples M(OAc)2 hydrate, where M = Co(II) and Zn(II) (0.09−0.125 g, 0.05 mol) in 2 mL of methanol, was added and heated for 10 min on a water bath at 75 °C and evaporated to dryness. The crude porphyrin was washed with water. The metal complexes were dried under vacuum and their yields were found to be almost quantitative. [Zn-PyTIPP]: 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6): 8.98 (d, 2H, J = 5.8 Hz), 8.79 (m, 8H), 8.16 (asymmetric t, 8H, J = 5.76 Hz, J = 8.2 Hz), 7.94 (d, 6H, J = 8.2 Hz). UV–vis in CH2Cl2/pyridine mixture: λmax, nm (log ε) 429(5.69), 562(4.15), 602(3.69). FAB-mass spectrum (m/z) for C43H24N5I3Zn: found 1057, Calcd. 1056.8. [Co-PyTIPP]: UV–vis in CH2Cl2/pyridine mixture: λmax, nm (log ε) 411(5.51), 531(4.20). MALDI-TOF mass spectrum (m/z) for C43H24N5I3Co: found 1050.96, Calcd. 1050.34.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of Metal Derivatives

The free-base porphyrins PyTIPP or PyDIPP (~0.05 g) were dissolved in 25 mL of CHCl3. To each of these samples M(OAc)2 hydrate, where M = Co(II) and Zn(II) (0.09-0.125 g, 0.05 mol) in 2 mL of methanol, was added and heated for 10 min on a water bath at 75 °C and evaporated to dryness. The crude porphyrin was washed with water. The metal complexes were dried under vacuum and their yields were found to be almost quantitative. [Zn-PyTIPP]: 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6): 8.98 (d, 2H, J = 5.8 Hz), 8.79 (m, 8H), 8.16 (asymmetric t, 8H, J = 5.76 Hz, J = 8.2 Hz), 7.94 (d, 6H, J = 8.2 Hz). UV-vis in CH2Cl2/pyridine mixture: λmax, nm (log ε) 429(5.69), 562(4.15), 602(3.69). FAB-mass spectrum (m/z) for C43H24N5I3Zn: found 1057, Calcd. 1056.8. [Co-PyTIPP]: UV-vis in CH2Cl2/pyridine mixture: λmax, nm (log ε) 411(5.51), 531(4.20). MALDI-TOF mass spectrum (m/z) for C43H24N5I3Co: found 1050.96, Calcd. 1050.34.

elements.content: Four milligrams (∼0.004 mmol) of H2-PyTIPP was dissolved in 2 mL of chloroform followed by few drops of ethyl benzoate and allowed to slowly evaporate at ambient conditions. X-ray quality crystals of the ethyl benzoate solvate (structure 1) were obtained after one week. Four milligrams (∼0.004 mmol) of Co-PyTIPP were dissolved in 1.5 mL of 4:1 chloroform/methanol (v/v) mixture, followed by a few drops of nitrobenzene, and allowed to evaporate slowly. X-ray quality crystals of the chloroform/nitrobenzene solvate (structure 2) were obtained after one week. Crystals of the zinc analogue Zn-PyTIPP were obtained as the nitrobenzene solvate (structure 2a) when 4.3 mg of PyTIPP in 1.5 mL of chloroform were mixed with 2 mg of zinc-acetate dissolved in a few drops of methanol, and the mixture was heated for a few minutes and a few drops of nitrobenzene were added. Chloroform-solvated crystals of 3 were obtained after slow crystallization of PyDIPP from a similar mixture of chloroform, methanol, and nitrobenzene. A mixture of DMF, pyridine, and nitrobenzene was used to obtain essentially solvent free crystals of Zn-PyDIPP (4). Crystals of 5 were afforded after dissolving PyDIPP in a mixture of chloroform and ethyl benzoate, which was heated for 5 min at 60 °C. They represent 2:1 benzoic acid solvate of PyDIPP, as a result of an apparent hydrolysis of the ester in these conditions. It should be pointed out that the crystallization of these species is still to a large extent an art as well as a science, and is oftentimes a stumbling block for the characterization of a larger variety of these interesting materials.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallization Procedures

Four milligrams (~0.004 mmol) of H2-PyTIPP was dissolved in 2 mL of chloroform followed by few drops of ethyl benzoate and allowed to slowly evaporate at ambient conditions. X-ray quality crystals of the ethyl benzoate solvate (structure 1) were obtained after one week. Four milligrams (~0.004 mmol) of Co-PyTIPP were dissolved in 1.5 mL of 4:1 chloroform/methanol (v/v) mixture, followed by a few drops of nitrobenzene, and allowed to evaporate slowly. X-ray quality crystals of the chloroform/nitrobenzene solvate (structure 2) were obtained after one week. Crystals of the zinc analogue Zn-PyTIPP were obtained as the nitrobenzene solvate (structure 2a) when 4.3 mg of PyTIPP in 1.5 mL of chloroform were mixed with 2 mg of zinc-acetate dissolved in a few drops of methanol, and the mixture was heated for a few minutes and a few drops of nitrobenzene were added. Chloroform-solvated crystals of 3 were obtained after slow crystallization of PyDIPP from a similar mixture of chloroform, methanol, and nitrobenzene. A mixture of DMF, pyridine, and nitrobenzene was used to obtain essentially solvent free crystals of Zn-PyDIPP (4). Crystals of 5 were afforded after dissolving PyDIPP in a mixture of chloroform and ethyl benzoate, which was heated for 5 min at 60 °C. They represent 2:1 benzoic acid solvate of PyDIPP, as a result of an apparent hydrolysis of the ester in these conditions. It should be pointed out that the crystallization of these species is still to a large extent an art as well as a science, and is oftentimes a stumbling block for the characterization of a larger variety of these interesting materials.

elements.content: The X-ray measurements (Nonius Kappa CCD diffractometer, Mo Kα radiation) were carried out at ca. 110 K, on crystals coated with a thin layer of amorphous hydrocarbon oil in order to minimize deterioration, possible structural disorder and related thermal motion effects, and to optimize the precision of the crystallographic results. The uniform identity of the formed crystal lattices in a given bulk reaction was confirmed in each case by repeated measurements of the unit-cell dimensions from different single crystallites. The crystal and experimental data for 1–5 are summarized in Table . These structures were solved by direct methods (SHELXS-96, SIR-97), and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 (SHELXL-97). All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were located in idealized/calculated positions, and were refined using a riding model, with U iso = 1.2 or 1.5 Ueq of the parent atom. Crystals of 1–4 reveal a considerable amount of partly disordered (even at 110 K) fragments, occlusion of disordered solvent, and diffracted poorly. Correspondingly, in their crystallographic evaluations the contribution of the disordered solvents was subtracted from the diffraction data by the SQUEEZE procedure with the aid of the PLATON software. The intensity data were corrected empirically for absorption effects; the calculated absorption coefficients in 1–4 account only for the main fragments of these structures (excluding the disordered crystallization solvent). Solvent accessible voids in 1 amount to 485 Å3. Two recognizable molecules of ethyl benzoate are severely disordered within these voids, and discrete atoms could not model them reliably. This crystal represents a 1:2 racemic twin. The relatively high residual peak of about 4 e Å−3 observed in the vicinity of an iodine atom represents most probably a diffraction ripple, resulting from an inadequate correction for absorption effects. Solvent accessible voids in 2 amount to 2440 Å3 (about 27% of the crystal volume), equally distributed between two sites at ½,0,0 and 0,½,½. The total residual electron count in these voids was assessed to be 1047 e. The solvent species (unknown mixture of about eight molecules of chloroform and/or nitrobenzene per unit-cell) are severely diffused within the intralattice voids, and could not be identified and modeled by discrete atoms. The conventional refinement based on the same structural model, which excludes the solvent converged at R1 = 0.14. One of the iodophenyl rings was found to exhibit partial rotational disorder as well. In 2a, the solvent accessible void centered around 0,½,0 amounts to 4323 Å3 (about 40% of the crystal volume). Recognizable fragments of nitrobenzene species appear to accommodate this void space. Conventional refinement based on a structural model that includes six nitrobenzene moieties with partial occupancies and isotropic thermal displacement parameters converged at R1 = 0.14. Because of very low precision of the structural parameters and distorted geometry of the solvent, it was excluded from the structural model in the final calculations. The crystallographic refinement of this structure based on the “squeezed” data is still characterized, however, by rather low precision and distorted atomic displacement parameters. Yet, the gross structure of the tetrameric assembly seems to be perfectly valid. Much smaller intralattice voids of ∼300 Å3/unit-cell (adequate to accommodate a single small organic moiety) were observed in the unit-cells of structures 3 (with one molecule of recognizable but severely disordered chloroform) and 4 (which are probably empty or contain traces of disordered water; thermal gravimetric analysis of 4 showed a negligible weight loss on heating the sample from room temperature to 400 °C), in which the solvent structure could not be properly modeled/identified by discrete atoms as well. The residual electron density in the voids of 3 and 4 was assessed to be 38 and 6 e per unit-cell, respectively. In all cases the crystallographic evaluations provided, however, reliable structural models of the porphyrin framework structures and of their supramolecular organization in the corresponding solids.

In 1–4, after subtracting the contribution of the solvent from the diffraction data (using the SQUEEZE procedure and Platon software). The R-factors in parentheses relate to calculations with the conventional unsqueezed data.

The molecular framework of PyTIPP has a polar axis due to the asymmetric substitution of the pyridyl and iodophenyl functional groups. Moreover, it lacks not only inversion symmetry, but also mirror symmetry, as the aryl substituents are not entirely perpendicular to the flat porphyrin core. Most commonly, the dihedral angles between the mean planes of the aryls and the porphyrin core in crystals are observed within 60–80°. This topological feature should be attributed to steric repulsion between the peripheral H-atoms of the pyrrole rings and those at the ortho positions of the aryl rings. A given conformation of this species frozen in the crystalline state will be therefore a chiral entity. The self-assembly of PyTIPP in the crystalline phase is directed by halogen bonds (the tendency of halogen atoms to involve in directional interactions with lone pair possessing atoms). It yields flat supramolecular layers of the porphyrin units interconnected to one another along the trans-related pyridyl-iodophenyl axis by N···I halogen bonds (Figure ). The corresponding N···I distances of 2.92 Å are considerably shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of the two atoms (ca. 3.5–3.8 Å), and the bond energy is estimated to be about 14 kJ/mol. In a perpendicular direction of the formed layer adjacent porphyrin units interact on both sides via apparent I···π interactions at iodine-to-aryl ring distances with 3.44 Å. The sideways-directed C−I bonds of one halogen-bonded linear array are oriented nearly perpendicular to the iodophenyl and pyridyl rings of adjacent arrays. Evidently, the supramolecular layers thus formed have a polar axis and are chiral, as all the N···I halogen bonds are oriented in the same direction, and all the component building blocks are related to one another by pure translation symmetry.

Results and Discussion

The molecular framework of PyTIPP has a polar axis due to the asymmetric substitution of the pyridyl and iodophenyl functional groups. Moreover, it lacks not only inversion symmetry, but also mirror symmetry, as the aryl substituents are not entirely perpendicular to the flat porphyrin core. Most commonly, the dihedral angles between the mean planes of the aryls and the porphyrin core in crystals are observed within 60-80°. This topological feature should be attributed to steric repulsion between the peripheral H-atoms of the pyrrole rings and those at the ortho positions of the aryl rings. A given conformation of this species frozen in the crystalline state will be therefore a chiral entity. The self-assembly of PyTIPP in the crystalline phase is directed by halogen bonds (the tendency of halogen atoms to involve in directional interactions with lone pair possessing atoms). It yields flat supramolecular layers of the porphyrin units interconnected to one another along the trans-related pyridyl-iodophenyl axis by N⋅⋅⋅I halogen bonds (Figure ). The corresponding N⋅⋅⋅I distances of 2.92 Å are considerably shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of the two atoms (ca. 3.5-3.8 Å), and the bond energy is estimated to be about 14 kJ/mol. In a perpendicular direction of the formed layer adjacent porphyrin units interact on both sides via apparent I⋅⋅⋅π interactions at iodine-to-aryl ring distances with 3.44 Å. The sideways-directed C-I bonds of one halogen-bonded linear array are oriented nearly perpendicular to the iodophenyl and pyridyl rings of adjacent arrays. Evidently, the supramolecular layers thus formed have a polar axis and are chiral, as all the N⋅⋅⋅I halogen bonds are oriented in the same direction, and all the component building blocks are related to one another by pure translation symmetry.

elements.content: In the crystal, the layered assemblies offset stack along the normal direction at an interlayer distance of approximately 4.5 Å. Remarkably, all the layers are aligned in the same direction, imparting chirality to the entire crystalline architecture. Yet, crystals of 1 represent racemic twins, that is, they are composed of domains of opposing chirality. Similar conglomerates of chiral ensembles were obtained by self-assembly of the Cu-PyTIPP and Zn(py)-PyTIPP (wherein the axial ligation capacity of zinc is used by a pyridine ligand) analogues in layered crystals, suggesting that the observed supramolecular chirality does not represent serendipity but rather a phenomenon of more fundamental significance, to be evaluated in more depth elsewhere.

elements.content: Successful strategies for the deliberate synthesis of stable discrete supramolecular squares, boxes, and capsules of the porphyrin species resorted to metal–ligand coordination chemistry. The metal sites can be either external bridging auxiliaries (e.g., Pd, Pt, Ru, or Re) or metal ions inserted in the porphyrin core which in addition to their bonds with the pyrrole N-atoms have axial coordination capacity as well (e.g., Zn, Mn, Rh). In order to bias the self-assembly into a cyclic trimeric or tetrameric aggregate, and prevent polymeric association, just a single coordination-active functional group (e.g., 4-pyridyl, 3-pyridyl, pyrazolyl, pyrimidyl) is allowed on the porphyrin unit while the other substituents are inert to coordination. Only a small number of cyclic tetramers sustained by direct perpendicular intercoordination of the individual metalloporphyrin units has been reported thus far, including our earlier study of a nanosized supermolecule of Zn-(3-pyridyl)-tris(4-hydroxyphenyl)porphyrin. We present here additional syntheses of such discrete supramolecular clusters of Co-PyTIPP and Zn-PyTIPP, which substantiate the validity of this approach to the construction of cyclic tetrameric entities, and confirm that the cyclic tetramer represents a stable entity for the building blocks in question. PyTIPP bears a single 4-pyridyl ligand, while the remaining meso-positions carry coordination-inactive iodophenyl fragments.

elements.content: The molecular structures of the two cyclic tetramers in 2 and 2a are illustrated in Figure . The core metal ions in both structures are five-coordinate. The observed coordination distances are Co−N(pyrrole) 1.96–1.99 Å, Co−N(pyridine) 2.19 Å, Zn−N(pyrrole) 2.06–2.08 Å, and Zn−N(pyridine) 2.14 Å. The smaller size of the cobalt ion causes a considerable saddle-type deformation of the porphyrin ring in order to accommodate the shorter Co−N(pyrrole) bonds. The two compounds represent similarly shaped open square supramolecular boxes, wherein the 4-pyridyl arm of one component is oriented nearly perpendicular the porphyrin core of a neighboring unit to form an effective coordinative linkage. The crystal packing of the porphyrin tetramers in 2 and 2a (the two compounds crystallized as solvates) is stabilized also by dipolar interactions between the peripheral iodophenyl groups of adjacent species.

elements.content: When the 4-pyridyl function is replaced by its 3-pyridyl ligand analogue, effective intercoordination requires inclined relative orientation of the interacting porphyrins, yielding a more compact tetrameric species, where two inward pyridyl groups overlap one-another (Figure ). In the case of the Zn-(3-pyridyl)-tris(4-hydroxyphenyl)porphyrin we were able to confirm by MS (MALDI-TOF) measurements that the tetrameric clusters are stable in solution as well, by detecting distinct peaks of decreasing intensity at positions corresponding to monomeric, dimeric, trimeric as well tetrameric porphyrin clusters. The occurrence of such multiple signals in the MS spectra could be due to fragmentation of the tetrameric product by ionization excitation in these energized experiments into lower oligomers. The latter phenomenon appears to be even more pronounced in the present study. MS spectra (in an α-cyano-4-hydroxycinnamic acid matrix) of Co-PyTIPP solution showed peaks corresponding to monomeric (m/z = 1050), dimeric (2099), and dimeric less one-iodine (1973) species. In spectra of Zn-PyTIPP solution appeared peaks that correspond to monomer (1056), dimer (2111), dimer with one iodine loss (1986), and trimer with two iodine loss (2915) moieties. The dissociation of the relatively weak C−I bonds under these experimental conditions is also apparent. When solid Zn-PyTIPP was used in the MALDI-TOF experiment, a very small peak was also observed at m/z = 3846, corresponding to a tetramer with three iodine loss. Failure to detect the tetrameric unit in solution in the present study may be associated also with the lower stability of the open square structures in the dynamic solution state.

elements.content: The PyDIPP scaffold bears two pairs of trans-related complementary pyridyl and iodophenyl functions, and thus appeared to be an excellent candidate for the tessellation of supramolecular layers by N···I halogen bonds along the two perpendicular directions. In an optimal case, such an assembly would represent an open grid network with ∼1.5 nm wide interporphyrin voids, as it was observed in the tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)porphyrin materials (Figure a). It appeared, however, that such networks could not be made until now with PyDIPP, most probably due to the rather low enthalpic stabilization provided by the halogen bonding interactions. These involve only four weak halogen bonds per a single square grid of four porphyrin units, as opposed to eight O−H···O hydrogen bonds (bond energy of each being ≥20 kJ/mol) per grid of the carboxyphenyl derivative, which seem to be insufficient to sustain such a large void space. Instead, the self-assembly of PyDIPP in 3 results in a more compact layered organization (Figure b). It is composed of a repeating unit of three rows of molecules, being sustained primarily by I···π, π···π, and weak C−H···N intermolecular interactions. Within the first two lower rows of molecules in Figure b, the iodophenyl arms of one porphyrin species are directed perpendicular to the π-system of the pyridyl groups of neighboring molecules (contacts of type ‘a’) at 3.38 Å. In addition, there is a considerable overlap between the parallel pyridyl rings of adjacent porphyrin units distant 3.30 Å from one another (contacts of type ‘b’ in Figure b). These two-row assemblies join together on both sides into an extended layer via a third row of differently oriented porphyrin species through weak attractive C−H···N contacts (contacts of type ‘c’ in Figure b). As in 1, the molecular layers thus formed are stacked in the crystal structure along the normal direction in an offset manner.

elements.content: Tetraarylporphyrins substituted with two trans-related pyridyl functions and metalated in their core with metal ions prone to octahedral coordination environment provide excellent building blocks in appropriate conditions for the construction of a 3-D coordination framework. In order to obtain such architectures, lack of competing ligands for coordination to the metal center, whether substituted on the porphyrin or present in the solvent mixture, is required. The Zn-PyDIPP scaffold is no exception. The iodine atoms have little affinity for coordination to the zinc ions, and therefore the dominant interaction that directs the self-assembly of the porphyrin units in 4 is the strong N(pyridyl)-Zn coordination at Zn−N = 2.357(6) Å, which is many times stronger (∼200 kJ/mol) than any specific interaction that may involve the iodophenyl functions. The multiple coordination mode is shown in Figure . Every metalloporphyrin monomer utilizes two trans-related pyridyl arms to associate with the metal center of two adjacent porphyrins along one axis, while its zinc ion links to two pyridyl functions of other units approaching from both sides of the molecular framework along a roughly perpendicular axis. This inter-porphyrin binding propagates through the crystal structure in three dimensions, yielding a single-framework coordination polymer of Zn-PyDIPP.

elements.content: In the supramolecular framework shown in Figure , the porphyrin species are arranged around the 3-fold axis of the crystal. The iodophenyl arms that are not part of the coordination framework, point either up or down inward and outward. They line the walls of the narrow channel voids that perforate the crystal around the 3-fold rotation axes. Space-filling illustration of the whole crystal structure viewed down this axis is shown in Figure a. Only a small number of examples of this structure type are known. They include coordination frameworks of zinc-tetrapyridyl-porphyrin, of manganese- and cobalt-tetrapyridyl-porphyrin, and of zinc-diphenyl-dipyridyl-porphyrin. These examples and 4, all have isomorphous and nearly isometric crystal structures, differing only in the width of the inter-porphyrin channels (Figure ). When the pyridyl groups line the channel walls the van der Waals diameter of these channels is within 0.5–0.6 nm, and incorporation of polar solvents within them is preferred. With phenyl substituents inside the channels, the size of the channels are slightly decreased to 0.4–0.5 nm, and inclusion of nonpolar solvents (as e.g., cyclohexane) becomes feasible. In 4, with the bulky iodine atoms on the interior the channels, the diameter is reduced to ≤0.3 nm, and only traces of water (as confirmed by the diffraction data as well as by TGA experiments) were trapped in the crystal lattice. All the structures of this type reveal high thermal stability up to nearly 400 °C, and preserve their structural integrity after expulsion of all the included solvent. The occurrence of the unique honeycomb polymeric organization with six-coordinate zinc ions in the porphyrin core (though zinc ions usually reveal weak propensity for octahedral coordination), further attests to the thermodynamic stability of the observed multi-porphyrin architecture. Yet, other stable polymeric constructs (1-D chains and 2-D networks) can also form in different reaction conditions.

elements.content: The outcome of supramolecular synthesis is as sensitive to the experimental conditions as is that of the conventional covalent synthesis. Therefore, failure to crystal engineer a desired product is not an uncommon event. In earlier reports, we referred to the destructive effect that competing solvation may have on the direct self-assembly of porphyrin entities into extended arrays. It related to tetra(carboxyphenyl)porphyrins in environments containing strong Lewis base reagents as pyridines or sulfoxides. The latter compete as effective proton acceptors in possible H-bonds with the carboxylic acid function, solvate the porphyrin moieties, and prevent direct hydrogen bonding between them. A similar episode occurred in the present work. The pyridyl substituents in PyDIPP intended to form halogen bonds with the iodine sites of other porphyrin molecules can be readily solvated by carboxylic acids, as the energy of the acid···pyridine synthon is near 42 kJ/mol, while that of the iodo···pyridine interaction is only about 14 kJ/mol. This was indeed the scenario when PyDIPP was heated in ethyl benzoate as crystallization solvent (compound 5). The benzoic acid, which dissociated from the ester, reacted with the pyridyl functions, yielding discrete molecules of 1:2 PyDIPP/benzoic acid solvate through O−H···N hydrogen bonds (at O···N = 2.67 Å). The crystalline architecture of 5, shown in Figure , is void of any specific porphyrin−porphyrin interactions, the most reactive pyridyl sites of PyDIPP being protected by molecules of the benzoic acid. The structure consists of columns of the porphyrin units stacked along the a-axis of the crystal, with molecules of the benzoic acid located between the porphyrin stacks.

elements.content: The above results demonstrate a number of useful guidelines in crystal engineering of supramolecular architectures involving porphyrins and metalloporphyrins substituted by two different combinations (1:3 in PyTIPP, and 2:2 in PyDIPP) of pyridyl and iodophenyl groups. The free-base PyTIPP with the asymmetric substitution pattern self-assembles into 2-D layers, wherein the N···I halogen bonds are the structure directing interactions. Most remarkably, these layered arrays are chiral as all molecules within them are oriented in the same direction and they lack inversion and mirror symmetries. Formulation of discrete tetrameric supermolecules is preferred with the Co-PyTIPP and Zn-PyTIPP platforms through intermolecular pyridyl-to-metal coordination. This adds to the accumulated experience that metalloporphyrins with axial coordination capacity to the metal center, a single coordination-active pyridyl substituent and three other coordination-inert groups, is a reliable protocol for the formulation of cyclic oligomeric constructs. On the other hand, metalloporphyrins with two trans-related pyridyl functions as in Zn-PyDIPP are prone to self-assemble into a uniquely robust single framework honeycomb architecture perforated by guest-accessible channels. The size of the latter can be controlled by the size of the noncoordinating substituents on the porphyrin moiety. Solids of this structure-type may reveal molecular-sieving features. The free-base PyDIPP yielded a compact layered organization sustained by various types of weak porphyrin-porphyrin interactions, including I···π, π···π, and C−H···N contacts. However, in the presence of a strong hydrogen-bonding reagent as benzoic acid it formed discrete units of the porphyrin solvate. The above observations provide valuable insights into the crystal engineering strategies of supramolecular porphyrin ensembles. They highlight the different synthons that can direct the self-assembly process of the porphyrin building blocks toward the formulation of flat 2-D networks, single-framework 3-D architectures, or discrete cyclic oligomers.
elements.clean_text:
Concluding Remarks

The above results demonstrate a number of useful guidelines in crystal engineering of supramolecular architectures involving porphyrins and metalloporphyrins substituted by two different combinations (1:3 in PyTIPP, and 2:2 in PyDIPP) of pyridyl and iodophenyl groups. The free-base PyTIPP with the asymmetric substitution pattern self-assembles into 2-D layers, wherein the N⋅⋅⋅I halogen bonds are the structure directing interactions. Most remarkably, these layered arrays are chiral as all molecules within them are oriented in the same direction and they lack inversion and mirror symmetries. Formulation of discrete tetrameric supermolecules is preferred with the Co-PyTIPP and Zn-PyTIPP platforms through intermolecular pyridyl-to-metal coordination. This adds to the accumulated experience that metalloporphyrins with axial coordination capacity to the metal center, a single coordination-active pyridyl substituent and three other coordination-inert groups, is a reliable protocol for the formulation of cyclic oligomeric constructs. On the other hand, metalloporphyrins with two trans-related pyridyl functions as in Zn-PyDIPP are prone to self-assemble into a uniquely robust single framework honeycomb architecture perforated by guest-accessible channels. The size of the latter can be controlled by the size of the noncoordinating substituents on the porphyrin moiety. Solids of this structure-type may reveal molecular-sieving features. The free-base PyDIPP yielded a compact layered organization sustained by various types of weak porphyrin-porphyrin interactions, including I⋅⋅⋅π, π⋅⋅⋅π, and C-H⋅⋅⋅N contacts. However, in the presence of a strong hydrogen-bonding reagent as benzoic acid it formed discrete units of the porphyrin solvate. The above observations provide valuable insights into the crystal engineering strategies of supramolecular porphyrin ensembles. They highlight the different synthons that can direct the self-assembly process of the porphyrin building blocks toward the formulation of flat 2-D networks, single-framework 3-D architectures, or discrete cyclic oligomers.

cln_elements.content:
All starting materials, reagents, and solvents were obtained commercially (Aldrich and Merck) and used without further purification.

Synthesis of Porphyrin Compounds

A total of 1.25 g (5.4 mmol) of 4-iodobenzaldehyde, 0.34 mL (3.6 mmol) of 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde were added to 35 mL of hot propionic acid at 120 °C. Then 0.5 mL of distilled pyrrole (7.21 mmol) was added, and the resulting solution was heated to refluxing for 90 min. The solvent was then removed by vacuum distillation, and the crude product was digested with hot water to remove traces of propionic acid, filtered, washed with water, and dried. The crude porphyrin mixture was dissolved in chloroform and loaded on a silica gel 60 (Merck) column using chloroform.
